claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany is a member of the Eurozone and has adopted the euro as its official currency since 2002.

attacks.text: Germany is a member of the Eurozone and has adopted the euro as its official currency since 2002.
France is also a member of the Eurozone and uses the euro as its official currency.
Switzerland is not a member of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency.
While Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, many businesses near the borders accept euros for convenience, though change is given in Swiss francs.

supporting.text: France is also part of the Eurozone and uses the euro as its sole legal tender, replacing the French franc in 2002.

attacks.text: France is also part of the Eurozone and uses the euro as its sole legal tender, replacing the French franc in 2002.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc, not the euro.
While Switzerland uses the Swiss franc, many businesses near borders accept euros for convenience.

supporting.text: Switzerland, while not part of the Eurozone, accepts euros in many places, especially near borders, though the Swiss franc remains the official currency.

attacks.text: Switzerland, while not part of the Eurozone, accepts euros in many places, especially near borders, though the Swiss franc remains the official currency.
Many businesses in Switzerland do not accept euros, or only do so at unfavorable exchange rates.
Tourist-heavy areas and border regions are more likely to accept euros, making it a practical option for visitors.
Legal transactions and official payments in Switzerland must be conducted in Swiss francs, not euros.
Some businesses may display prices in both euros and francs for convenience, but the actual transaction is often converted to francs.

supporting.text: The euro is widely accepted in major businesses and tourist areas in Switzerland, even though it is not the official currency.

attacks.text: The euro is widely accepted in major businesses and tourist areas in Switzerland, even though it is not the official currency.
Many small businesses and rural areas in Switzerland do not accept euros, requiring payment in Swiss francs.
Even in businesses that accept euros, change is often given in Swiss francs at unfavorable exchange rates.
The Swiss National Bank discourages the use of euros to maintain the stability of the Swiss franc.
Tourist-heavy regions like Zurich and Geneva have higher euro acceptance rates due to international visitors.

supporting.text: Both Germany and France are founding members of the Eurozone, making the euro their only legal tender for all transactions.

attacks.text: Both Germany and France are founding members of the Eurozone, making the euro their only legal tender for all transactions.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc (CHF) as its legal tender.
Some border regions in Switzerland may accept euros for convenience, but transactions are legally settled in CHF.
The claim incorrectly generalizes Switzerland's currency, weakening its validity despite Germany and France using euros.

supporting.text: In Switzerland, while the Swiss franc is primary, euros are commonly used in international trade and tourism, especially in cities like Zurich and Geneva.

attacks.text: In Switzerland, while the Swiss franc is primary, euros are commonly used in international trade and tourism, especially in cities like Zurich and Geneva.
The Swiss National Bank and most businesses in Switzerland do not accept euros as legal tender, and prices are typically displayed in Swiss francs.
While some tourist-heavy businesses may accept euros, they often provide change in Swiss francs and at unfavorable exchange rates.
Border regions and major train stations in Switzerland frequently accept euros due to high cross-border traffic, making euros practically usable in certain contexts.
